text:
- [Speaker With Soft
Tone] Any company retail
is a large company that is looking
to drive innovation and deliver results
across their different lines of business,
including their contact center,

quality assurance, and
marketing departments, in order

to deliver superior experiences
for their retail customers.
They have a strategic goal this year,

to leverage Generative
AI, to improve customer

and employee satisfaction while
reducing operational costs.

This demo will showcase
a real-world example of

how Amazon Q can be leveraged
across an enterprise.
Let's begin by walking through

how any company retail
leverages Generative AI
to provide superior customer service
in their contact center.
Let's meet our agent, John.

John gets an inbound
contact from a customer

who has some questions about
one of their premium products
after doing some research online.

At the moment of contact, John
has a single pane of glass

with everything he
needs at his fingertips.

John sees information
about the customer, Nikki,

including her member profile,
her entire service history,
and past purchases, all details

that will help him
personalize the interaction
while providing fast service.
John accepts the contact.
During the conversation with Nikki.

John gets real-time Generative
AI-powered recommendations
such as responses and actions to help him

answer Nikki's questions
about the product.

It's like he has the best
agent by his side helping him.
Amazon Q in Connect surfaces solutions

based on any company retail's
enterprise knowledge base.
This experience allows John

to focus more on personalizing
the experience for Nikki

versus putting her on hold
and searching for information
in multiple places.

This is one of the ways that
Generative AI can be leveraged
to both improve operational efficiency
and improve the customer experience.

Nikki is delighted with the
information John provides her

and ask John if he can help
her complete her purchase.
John has dynamically surfaced guided steps
to quickly help Nikki and provide her

with other critical important
details about her order.

By leveraging the power
of Amazon Q in Connect,
any company retail

ensures they provide
superior customer service
at scale and make every agent superhuman.

Something powerful is
happening in the background.

During the conversation,
Nikki, the customer mentioned

to Agent John that she initially
did some research online

and found conflicting product
reviews, which prompted her
to call in and talk to someone.
Is this connected to something bigger?
Let's take a look at how Amazon Q

can help connect these
dots across the enterprise.
- [Speaker With Deep Tone] Now let's see
how Amazon Q is helping another department
inside any company.

Mary, manages quality assurance
for any company retail,
analyzing the thousands

of site interactions from
their three retail departments.

She has everything she needs
at her fingertips to understand
how operations is performing
against their key performance indicators
across all departments at scale.

She uses the business
intelligence capabilities

of Amazon QuickSight to
evaluate the overall health
of the website operations.
Using Amazon in QuickSight, Mary is able

to reduce the time she
spends creating dashboards.

She pulls insights from her
dashboards by asking Q questions

and receives multiple
visuals from her dashboard
to support the answer Q provides.

She also uses Amazon Q to
quickly generate narratives

of her dashboards findings,
which she can then share
with her stakeholders.

Amazon Q in QuickSight
makes it easy for Mary
to build her dashboards visuals

without having deep knowledge
and data visualization tools
like SQL, for example, Mary asks Amazon Q

to build a visual showing
transaction spent by category
as a donut chart.

Amazon Q creates one in
seconds, which she then adds
to her QuickSight analysis.

Behind the scenes, Mary
continues to use Amazon Q
to build a complete QuickSight dashboard
of her company's data.
Now with her published dashboard,

her team can use Amazon Q
to get an executive summary
of the dashboard's key insights,
and ask Amazon Q questions on their data.

As Mary reviews the
executive summary Q-generated
and drills down on the insights,

she notices a potential
problem with the data
for product reviews.
Mary decides to ask Amazon Q for ratings

for each department to drill
down further, she's looking

for more context around
the low product reviews
for some of their items.

Amazon Q responds with
a multi-visual answer

to help give context
to the data's insights.
The several visuals reveal a common trend

of low ratings associated
with the shoe category,

by the large difference
in ratings compared
to the other two departments,

she believes there is
something wrong with this data.
Mary wants to create a report

and give it to the IT team
for further investigation

based on these findings.
She uses Amazon Q
to generate a report

that summarizes why product
reviews are low for some
of the company's site's product listings.

Then, she shares the report
with key stakeholders
for visibility and request action.
Using her prompt,

Amazon Q builds a data
story using the visuals
and insights it pulls from her dashboard.

Before sending the report
over to IT, Mary reviews it
and makes small edits
using Amazon Q's generative editor tool.

Mary then wants to review
what she has built.
Mary previews the story
and sees that Amazon Q
calls out the potential fraudulent reviews
in their data that will be good

for the IT team to know
in their investigation.
Now she's ready to share these.

Adding Susan and other relevant
stakeholders to the story.

Using Amazon Q in QuickSight,
Mary is able to quickly
and easily build dashboards.
Amazon Q also gives her detailed insights,
which she may have missed before,

and generates a data story
using her data's insights.
Now that Mary has sent her data story
to Susan on the IT team.

Susan can review the
insights Amazon Q pulled

from the company site data on
product reviews to dig deeper.

Susan notices the section
calling out fraudulent reviews
and understands that the customer, Nikki,

also noticed some
conflicting product reviews.
She decides to start here

and use Amazon Q Business
to assist her investigation.

Susan starts by looking up
information on fake reviews.

Susan looks to see if
the sources are fine,

and Q has cited the sources for
Susan to check if she wants.

Susan continues by looking up
information on fake reviews.
Susan wants to leverage the wealth
of information across her organization

to evaluate relevant IT
programs and best practices.

She then leverages Amazon
Q's advanced capabilities

to generate a draft plan to
resolve the fake reviews issue.

Based on her research,
she puts together a plan

and submits a ticket to any
company retail's developer team.

Susan now creates a ticket
to prevent fake reviews.
Susan fills-out the ticket information
and submits the ticket.

Susan enters the details about
the topic that she would like
to learn more about and what she needs
as a prompt into Amazon Q.

Susan would like an app that
captures similar information
to generate similar outputs,
so she clicks the button to create an app
from this conversation.

A pop-up appears showing
that an app is being created.

Then a screen shows the suggested
prompt to create the app.
Susan sees a pop-up to leave feedback

for her Q administrator about
the quality of the prompt,
but she skips that step.
She reviews the prompt that was suggested

and makes slight
modifications to create an app
that takes three inputs from the user
to generate two outputs
and a form to submit a ticket to Jira.
Then clicks generate to create her app.

Susan sees her app being
created within seconds.

She knows that the input
cards have a blue header

and that output cards
have a purple header.

She decides to arrange the
cards in a user-friendly way.

She likes the card
titles, text placeholders,

and default values that
Q generated for her,
so she doesn't change those.

Susan tests the app by
entering cross-site scripting
as a well-known web issue, any company.com
as the affected entity
and highest as the priority

with the reasons why the web
team needs to prioritize a fix

for this.
Susan clicks run

and sees how the output
cards get filled in seconds

with content that is accurate
and customized to her inputs
and data source requirements.

Susan sees that the Jira
plugin card has the details

that she needs to submit
this as a service ticket
to her company's web team.

She completes any missing
fields, checks the description
that was entered by Q, click submit,

and waits a few seconds
to get confirmation
that a ticket has been created.
With her Q app working as intended,
Susan clicks publish to add her Q app
to the Q Apps Library.
Her app is immediately published

in any company's Q App Library
and is visible to everyone.
She tests this by going to the library

and filtering by marketing
and finds her app listed.
She gives her app its first heart-like.
Martin.
- [Speaker With Soft Tone] A developer
at any company retail.
Reviews the report created earlier by Mary

and decides to use Amazon Q
Developer to discuss the issue.

Martin discusses the issue
with Amazon Q Developer
to brainstorm possible fixes,
to address the issues in the submit API.

Q developer suggests a few
changes that Martin could make.
He identifies two quick code changes
that he wants to make now.

The first is validate the
input is reasonably long,
and the second is ensure

that a user can only create
one review for each product.

He considers, including some
alternatives in a later sprint.

To add the input validation,
Martin uses a comment
to prompt Q to ensure

that the description is
at least 12 characters.
Q suggests code to enforce this validation

and Martin reviews the
suggestion and accepts it.

New reviews should
overwrite a prior review
from the same user.

Martin is unsure how to
update the SQL statement

to use an upset, so he asks
Q to rewrite it for him.

Q provides him an answer
and Martin accepts it.
Now he can push the code for code review

and once approved, can
complete the ticket.

Amazon Q is helping any
company retail deliver results
across their different lines of business.

In their contact center
with Amazon Q in Connect,
in their quality assurance department

with Amazon Q in QuickSight,
across their business

and marketing teams with
Amazon Q Business and Q Apps

and with their developers
with Amazon Q Developer.
In this demo, you saw one example of

how Amazon Q capabilities
accelerate business outcomes

for companies across all
sizes and industries.

We are excited to learn more
about your business outcomes
and how you can leverage Generative AI

across your enterprise
to achieve your goals.
